In the last problem, we explored contexts that were linear by noticing that

  • As the independent variable changes by a constant amount, there is a constant amount of change in the dependent variable.
  • The graph representing Alana's pledge plan crossed the y - axis at the point (0,5). Leanne's pledge plan crossed the y-axis at the point (0,10). Gilberto's pledge plan crossed the y- axis at the point (0,0). These points are called the y-intercepts. The y-intercept is the point where the line crosses the y-axis, or when x = 0.

In this problem, we will continue to explore linear relationships in new contexts.

  • What information does the y-intercept represent?
  • How might it be useful in solving problems?
